Award.AwardTitle: Experimental Investigation of Deep Penetration in Sand

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project examines the fundamentals of the problem of deep penetration in sand. The deep penetration problem contains virtually all the challenges that geomechanicians may face: large displacements, large rotations, large strains, strain localization, crushing, and a moving soil-metal boundary. The impact of the research therefore is dual: it will advance the understanding of a problem with applications to diverse fields, including projectile penetration into the ground, design of pile foundations and interpretation of the cone penetration test, but it will also help advance the understanding of fundamental processes that happen in granular (particulate) media, such as strain localization and particle crushing and how all of these complex processes should be handled in computational simulations. Benefits for society therefore are multiple, including the general advancement of the science of granular media, economies in foundation design, a better understanding of an application (projectile penetration) that is vital to the defense industry, the production of a database of images that can be used in education and research, and the training of researchers in advanced technology and computer simulations.

The research specifically uses the powerful combination of calibration chamber testing and the digital image correlation (DIC) technique to study cone penetration in crushable sands. A unique half-cylindrical chamber with a flat Plexiglass wall that allows observation of the vertical motion of half-circular penetrometers will be used to acquire images of the penetration process under various conditions with state-of-the-art high-resolution digital cameras and microscopes. The images will be processed in two ways: using DIC to obtain the displacement and strain fields in the soil and an algorithm that produces the particle size distribution of the soil from an image of it. The penetration resistance, local stresses, and the displacement and strain field dataset may be viewed as an experimental solution to the penetration boundary-value problem. Particle size gradation will be assessed during the entire penetration process, thereby enabling the research team to consider the relationship between crushing, wherever it occurs, penetration resistance and the displacement and strain fields. The calibration chamber tests are complemented by a complete laboratory testing program to produce data that can later be used in validation of theoretical simulations and development of methods of analysis and design. The high-quality experimental data will include data from tests in a unique Hopkinson bar especially designed to test soil under uniaxial or triaxial conditions. Work will also be done to advance computational simulation capabilities of penetration problems using the material point method.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The deep penetration problem contains virtually all the challenges that geomechanicians face: large displacements, large rotations, large strains, strain localization, crushing, and a moving soil-penetrometer boundary. As such, it is an ideal problem to test the accuracy of simulation methods. In this research, we studied these different aspects of the deep penetration problem using the powerful combination of laboratory testing, calibration chamber experiments, digital image correlation (DIC) analysis, and X-ray Computed tomography (XCT) scanning. Furthermore, to study the effect of microscale sand properties on the macroscale sand behavior, we selected multiple silica sands with different particle characteristics in our experimental program. 

Laboratory experiments were carried out at Purdue and at the Argonne National Lab to accurately quantify the particle size distribution, particle morphology, particle crushing strength, packing density limits, and stress-strain behavior of the test sands under uniaxial and triaxial loading conditions. Quantification of these intrinsic sand properties allowed us to gain insights into their macroscopic behavior and also allowed us to track the evolution of these intrinsic properties in deep penetration environments.

We studied the change in the behavior of the test sands due to crushing at large mean stresses using 1D compression experiments carried out in a special X-ray Microscope (XRM). Analysis of the XCT data from the XRM allowed us to study the evolution of particle size, particle shape, and inter-particle contact orientations (sand fabric) under high compressive stresses. Results showed that inter-particle contact orientations remain relatively stable at stress levels lower than the yield stress in compression. However, when the applied stress crosses the yield stress and the sand particles start to crush, the inter-particle contact orientations in the sample become more randomly oriented, resulting in a more isotropic fabric.

In addition to the laboratory experiments, we also carried out numerous cone penetration experiments in a special half-cylindrical calibration chamber equipped with observation windows. These windows allowed us to capture digital images of the penetrometer and the surrounding sand during the experiments. These images were analyzed to obtain the displacement and strain fields in the sand domain using DIC analysis. In our initial experiments, we studied the effects of surface roughness and loading direction on the model penetrometer's shaft resistance. We found that the surface roughness had a pronounced effect on the shaft resistance in dense sand: average unit shaft resistance was considerably higher for rough surfaces (with Rn=0.063 and 0.145) than for the smooth surface (Rn=0.002).

We also carried out penetration experiments in the calibration chamber using shallow and deep penetrometers to compare and contrast the displacements, strains, and shear bands in deep and shallow penetration environments. We developed a novel DIC-based methodology to visualize the shear band ("slip surface") patterns that develop around penetrometers. Our analysis showed that the shear localization around a shallow penetrometer is somewhat diffused, approximately taking the wedge-and-fan shape. However, the localization of shear strains around deep penetrometersis more intensely concentrated near the penetrometer surface.

To quantify the crushing and fabric around the penetrometer, we developed novel agar- and resin-impregnation techniques to extract minimally disturbed sand samples from the calibration chamber after completion of the experiments. We employed this technique to collect sand samples around the penetrometer tip after penetration experiments in dense and medium-dense sands. The extracted samples were scanned using the XRM to obtain XCT data of the samples. We used the XCT data to reconstruct the sand particles' 3D geometric models in selected regions in the sample. We then analyzed these 3D geometric models to quantify particle crushing and sample fabric in the regions of interest. Results showed that crushing was localized near the penetrometer surface (closer to the penetrometer's shoulder) and that more significant crushing takes place in dense sands than in medium-dense sand. These observations were attributed to the higher mean stress and shear strain near the penetrometer tip in the dense sample. The analysis of the fabric of the sample is currently underway.

The overall impact of this research project was two-pronged: (1) it helped us advance our understanding of the penetration problem in sands and (2) it helped us advance the understanding of fundamental processes that happen in granular (particulate) media, such as strain localization and particle crushing. The cone penetration problem has applications to diverse fields, such as projectile penetration into the ground, design of pile foundations, and interpretation of the cone penetration test. It is one of the most challenging boundary-value problems in geomechanics, so the data set offers unique benchmarking data. Greater understanding of fabric evolution, shear strain localization and crushing has equally important reach. Therefore, benefits for society are multiple, including the general advancement of the science of granular media, economies in foundation design, and a better understanding of an application (probe or projectile penetration in particulate media) that is vital to the industry at large.
